misconceptions.name: Implemented an entirely different problem (distance formula instead of grade calculator)
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute the distance between two points instead of reading a numeric grade and printing the corresponding letter grade as specified. As a result, none of the rubric requirements for reading a grade, using conditional ranges, or mapping to letter grades are addressed.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can solve this question by writing a program that reads two points and prints the distance between them.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this question, the program must read a single numeric grade from 0 to 100 and use conditional logic to determine and print the correct letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) according to the given ranges.
symptoms: Program prompts for x and y coordinates instead of a single grade value
No conditional statements to check grade ranges
Output describes a distance, not a letter grade
No mapping from numeric ranges to characters A–F
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely misreading or confusing the assignment with a different exercise about computing distance between two points.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem prompt carefully and design the program around the required inputs and outputs: read one numeric grade, then use an if/else-if/else chain to test the grade ranges and print the corresponding letter.
related_concepts: Designing conditionals based on numeric ranges
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program is focused on distance computation with coordinates and makes no reference to grades or letter outputs.

evidence.note: The code reads coordinates and computes distance, with no grade input, no conditional grade ranges, and no letter grade output.

misconceptions.name: Submitted code for incorrect problem
misconceptions.description: The student provided code that calculates the distance between two points instead of implementing the required Grade Calculator program. The core conditional logic necessary for assigning letter grades is entirely missing.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student either submitted the wrong file or fundamentally misunderstood the assignment requirements, focusing on a geometric calculation instead of conditional logic and input handling for grading.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must read a single integer/double as a grade, and then use if/else if/else structures to compare this grade against specified numeric ranges (90-100, 80-89, etc.) and print the corresponding letter grade.
symptoms: Code calculates distance using Math.sqrt()
Code prompts for x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of 'Enter grade'
No conditional (if/else) statements related to numeric grades
misconceptions.root_cause: Failure to follow assignment instructions or misfiling/submitting code from a different exercise.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the problem description carefully and implement the logic to read a single grade and use branching statements (if-else) to determine and print the letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code (DistanceBetweenPoints.java) clearly implements a formula for distance calculation, making it 100% incorrect for the 'Grade Calculator' problem.

evidence.note: The class name and implementation are entirely dedicated to calculating distance, not calculating a grade.

misconceptions.name: Non-standard variable naming convention (ALL CAPS)
misconceptions.description: The student uses all-uppercase names (e.g., X1, DISTANCE) for local, non-final variables. In Java, this convention is standardly reserved only for constants (`final static`).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that uppercase is an acceptable or required naming convention for all variables.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Standard Java convention uses camelCase (e.g., x1, distance) for local variables and fields. ALL_CAPS_SNAKE_CASE is reserved for constants.
symptoms: Variable names are X1, Y1, DX, DY, DISTANCE
misconceptions.root_cause: Lack of knowledge or adherence to standard Java naming conventions and style guides.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: In Java, use camelCase for variables (e.g., `distance`, `input`). Reserve all caps for constants defined using the 'final' keyword.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The variables X1, Y1, X2, Y2, DX, DY, and DISTANCE are all declared in ALL CAPS and are not constants.

evidence.note: All local variables are named in ALL CAPS.

misconceptions.name: Complete task mismatch - wrong problem solved
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code for calculating distance between two points instead of implementing a grade calculator. This is a fundamental misunderstanding of the assignment requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they were asked to write a distance calculator program, or submitted the wrong file entirely.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading a numeric grade (0-100) and converting it to a letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) based on the specified ranges. The student should have implemented conditional logic to map grade ranges to letters.
symptoms: Code reads x1, y1, x2, y2 coordinates instead of a single numeric grade
Code calculates Euclidean distance instead of determining letter grade
No conditional statements checking grade ranges
Output displays distance instead of letter grade
misconceptions.root_cause: Student either submitted code from a different assignment, did not read the problem statement carefully, or misunderstood the requirements entirely.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully. The task requires: (1) reading one numeric grade value, (2) using if/else statements to check which range it falls into, (3) outputting the corresponding letter. Start over with a fresh approach focused on the grade calculator requirements.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Absolute certainty - the submitted code solves a completely different problem (distance calculation) than what was assigned (grade calculator).

evidence.note: Code reads four coordinate values (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a single grade value as required by the problem.

evidence.snippet:
DISTANCE = Math.sqrt(DX * DX + DY * DY);

      System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + DISTANCE);
evidence.note: Code calculates Euclidean distance and outputs it, rather than determining and outputting a letter grade.

misconceptions.name: Implemented distance formula instead of grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The program reads four coordinate values and computes the distance between two points instead of reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and mapping it to a letter grade using conditionals as required.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe the task is to write a program that reads two points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2) and computes the distance between them.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read a single numeric grade between 0 and 100 and use conditional statements to determine and print the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) based on the specified ranges.
symptoms: Program prompts for x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of a single grade
No conditionals or Boolean expressions for grade ranges
Output describes distance between points rather than a letter grade
misconceptions.root_cause: Misinterpretation of the problem specification or reuse of an unrelated solution template without adapting it to the current task.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully. Change the input to a single numeric grade (0-100), remove the distance formula, and implement an if-else chain that checks the grade against the A/B/C/D/F ranges and prints the correct letter.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire structure of the program (variable names, prompts, calculations, and output) matches a distance-between-points problem and contains no elements related to grade calculation or letter mapping.

evidence.note: The entire program is devoted to reading two points and computing their distance; it never reads a grade or computes a letter grade as required by the problem.

misconceptions.name: Complete functional mismatch (Incorrect Problem)
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a solution for calculating the distance between two points (using the Pythagorean theorem approach) instead of solving the assigned Grade Calculator problem. All requirements of the rubric are unmet because the intended grading logic is completely absent.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe this task required calculating the distance between two points, perhaps confusing it with a previous or different problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The requirement was to implement logic for reading a single numeric grade and outputting a letter grade based on predefined thresholds.
symptoms: Code calculates distance between points instead of determining a letter grade.
Input prompts ask for x1, y1, x2, y2, not 'Enter grade'.
Variables defined are related to coordinates (X1, Y1, DX, DISTANCE), not grades.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misreading or misunderstanding the assignment requirements, potentially reusing code from a different exercise.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Discard the distance calculation logic. Start fresh by focusing on the required inputs (one numeric grade) and outputs (a letter grade based on conditional logic).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The supplied code is 100% irrelevant to the problem description (Grade Calculator) and implements a completely different, unrelated application (Distance Between Points).

evidence.note: The entire main logic calculates the distance between two points using coordinate inputs, which is not the required task (Grade Calculator).

misconceptions.name: Submitted Wrong Problem Solution
misconceptions.description: The student submitted a distance calculator program instead of a grade calculator. The code reads two coordinate pairs and computes Euclidean distance, which is unrelated to the grade conversion task.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have submitted code from a different assignment or misread the problem requirements entirely.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputting a letter grade (A/B/C/D/F) based on specified ranges.
symptoms: Code reads x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of a grade
Code outputs distance calculation instead of letter grade
No conditional logic for grade boundaries
Class name is DistanceBetweenPoints, not GradeCalculator
misconceptions.root_cause: Either copied wrong code from a different assignment, or misread/misunderstood the problem statement.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Start over: read a single integer grade, use if-else statements to check which range it falls into (90-100, 80-89, 70-79, 60-69, or <60), and output the corresponding letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code solves a completely different problem with different inputs, outputs, and logic. This is not a minor misconception but a fundamental mismatch.

evidence.note: The entire program calculates distance between two points rather than converting a grade to a letter. This is the wrong problem solution.
